from getting the help they need.
Shatterproof is a national nonprofit dedicated to ending the devastation addiction causes
families.
We are changing laws, creating a community of support, and providing evidence-based resources
for prevention, treatment, and recovery.
If you or a loved one is impacted by addiction, find support at Shatterproof.org.
A dark prophecy foretold her death.
Then, through fire, it came to pass.
And the faithful mourned.
But it wasn't the hand of God that lit that flame.
Mortal sin.
A new podcast from Dateline and from me, Josh Mankiewicz.
Listen to the latest episodes each week completely free.
Just search Mortal sin wherever you get your podcasts.
Lemonade.
Welcome to the bubble, the Zandy Slavitt.
And Zach.
Hey Zach, how are you doing?
Pretty good, good to be back.
Thanks for coming back on the show.
How's your school work going?
Good, um, almost done.
Take three more weeks.
Good, I hope you're great.
You're good.
Pretty good, yeah.
The show is very interested in that.
So we're going to, um, replay an episode for, uh, for this week's show.
So let's talk about the episode we're going to replay.
Yeah, it was one of my favorite episodes.
Great.
Do you want to describe what it is?
Yeah, it was, um, how to talk to family members about complying with COVID regulations.
Yeah, it's an interesting one.
It was our very first toolkit.
And it was before a lot of people are listening to the show.
So you might not have heard it, but if you have, it's one I've played over and over again.

We asked people to submit questions about if they had situations either at the office or with family or with friends where people had different philosophies about whether they should wear masks or socially distance.
And they had some very tough questions that we had to really great people on who were answering those questions.
I mean, do you think that people your own age, are they mostly compliant or is it hard to be compliant or does it vary? What do you think?
Probably varies, but in my experience, I feel like probably not that much.
And I think a lot of college kids already got COVID, especially like some of the bigger schools.
So it's hard to like keep track of who is being safe and who isn't and who's immune and all that.
Got it.
Okay. Well, this will be great and interesting show.
We have one more thing we want to tell you about before we begin the show.
And that is our September donation.
We are donating $7,477.13.
That's 7.4, 7.7, 1.3, to a place called Sakeena Halal, which is an amazing place in Washington, D.C.
It's run by a man named Abdul Manan, and they serve basically Halal food there.
But the difference is that they invite homeless people into the restaurant or anybody that doesn't have the ability to pay.
And they can come in as much as they want. They don't have to prove anything.
They eat with the rest of the diners. And he's been doing this ever since he opened.
It's been absolutely incredible.
The owner is someone who's just been out, goes out into the park, offers to get fresh clothes and to help get the clothes cleaned for people who don't have a place to do that.
And his restaurant's gotten into trouble during COVID-19.
And we thought it would be a great place to make a donation.
So thank you so much because we couldn't make this donation without you listening to our show and listening to our commercials,
which we read to you. And so very much appreciated. I know this is going to make a difference in keeping more people who aren't eating fed in Washington, D.C.
If you're ever there, stop by the restaurant. It's a great place.
So, Sake, should we put on the episode?
Yeah, it's from the episode. And thanks for having me back.
Happy Thanksgiving.
We have two wonderful guests today. I don't think they would profess to have all the answers.
But I've known them both for quite some time. And I think they're going to be incredibly helpful in providing perspective.
So let me introduce them to you. The first guest is Natalie Davis.
She's the co-founder of United States of Care. And she leads the public affairs function.
Natalie is one of the country's leading thinkers in people centered health care design. How do we create policies and a health care system that meets the needs of real people?
She's done a tremendous amount of research here on how people communicate and talk to each other in health care.
You'll find it incredibly helpful here. Lonnie Chen, who, if you listened to an earlier episode, was on the podcast along with Ron Kline when we talked about the competency episode.
And Lonnie is a senior policy advisor at Hoover Institute. He was a campaign policy advisor, senior campaign advisor to Mitt Romney and his presidential campaign.

He and I have done some bipartisan sharing with Congress on the topic of health care. He also happens to be the chair of a hospital in California where one of the first patients came in with COVID-19.
And so he has great firsthand reaction and I think can help us understand how different people are approaching these topics. So welcome to both of you.
Thanks, Andy. Thank you.
And as you can tell, you'll be able to tell their voice apart. So I won't have to say this once Natalie and this one's Lonnie.

So just to open up, I'm going to get to some questions. We put out a question literally eight hours ago asking people if they were having any situations that were difficult in communicating to people around the world.
And people around how they feel about keeping themselves safe or their families safe with COVID-19 and the pandemic.
And the questions started pouring in two a minute. We won't have time to cover all of them, but I think the ones we cover will be helpful to almost all of the questions.
So this is sounds like a big problem. It sounds like a crisis within the crisis.

It's not necessarily going to even get better in the near term. So I guess my just opening question for both of you is, a, do you personally have any experience dealing with that type of situation in your own families or friend group?

And what's your general approach or do you have any overall thoughts and advice on how people should approach situation like this before we get into the actual questions Natalie, can we begin with you?

Sure. You know, it's not surprising to me that questions are coming in so quickly. We are at another turning point of what new normal looks like. And with anxieties high and with information changing constantly, it's not surprising to me that there are new social situations coming up all the time that people are trying to navigate.

The way my husband and I have been thinking about this is honestly about every two weeks, we sit down and say, okay, what are we comfortable with as new guidance has come out as our city opens up and others do and don't.

We sit down and say, okay, what is this? What do we now know about the virus that changes how we want to interact socially and we kind of come up with here's what we're comfortable with and here's what we're not comfortable with and kind of are able to do that together, which I think full for and talk to our kids about how things are changing.

And then have found a way to kind of set up boundaries with our loved ones, let's say, here's what we're comfortable with. We love to get together. How are you living your life right now? What are you comfortable with?

And that has led for some great opportunities to talk about how we're all thinking about the world right now. It unfortunately has led to some moments where we say we can't hang out with people because of the jobs they have, which is really unfortunate that they are helping set up the country.
For a success either in delivering food in delivering packages, a nurse, a police officer. And so we have to think about creative ways where both parties feel really comfortable getting together.
And the way we found to do that is being really kind of firm with our boundaries, but really empathetic with the boundaries.
Other people are setting up. We know that they're not there to hurt us. They're just seeing this virus as something different.
And the truth of their reality is the same as the truth of our reality. And we just have to figure out a way to kind of coexist.
And they've been kind of hard conversations because there are times we see the world differently, but with boundaries means that we want to find a way to kind of live together.
It's a respect for the relationship and being able to come and continue to see each other or know that we have to put that off for a little bit.
And then my husband, the humorist, always leads with, I just homeschooled four kids and I'm not going to go do this activity.
That puts how I just lived the last four months at Jeopardy because of something that I feel pre-oppression to do, which I'm just not going to.
So, you know, leading with if there's time for humor, knowing that four kids at home for four months is nothing you want to pretend like it wasn't a big deal.
I just saw a meme which someone shared with me which said, don't want to wear a mask, excited to homeschool again.
Right, right, right. And that is how we've talked about, you know, the economy opening back up is great and it does mean the sacrifice of wearing masks and social distancing.
So all of these things that allow us to see each other might hamper us into how we used to see each other, but it is a way to finally see each other when we have it for months.
Got it. Thanks, Natalie. Lonnie, how would you answer that?
Yeah, I think that's a lot of very good counsel from Natalie.
You know, I would just stress transparency and clarity, I think, just in terms of how one thinks about this and how you deal with it.

I mean, transparency is important because in these conversations you have with people, you know, I think the worst thing is to sort of say, look, here's something that we are deciding and to not make it clear, particularly if you have an ongoing or a long-term relationship with someone

or family or a friend or whatever it might be. And to not be clear about why it is that you're thinking what you're thinking. I think then people will kind of wonder, well, you know, do you think it's me? Do you think I'm the one who hasn't been, you know, obeying the rules and therefore that makes me unworthy to be, you know,

your hangout partner for the day or whatever it might be, having some transparency and to say, look, you know, here's how I'm approaching this or here's how we're approaching setting boundaries around who we're seeing and the kinds of activities we're taking on.

You know, I think that's very important so that people understand, look, you know, here's where I'm coming from and here's why I'm thinking. And then clarity around, you know, here's what I'm hearing about the science around the virus.

Here's what I'm hearing about why we're setting limitations in this way. And, you know, just recognizing and understanding that because the other part of this Andy that makes it hard is that, you know, you've got listeners from all over the country and in different parts of the country,
there are different societal expectations. There are different norms around what's open and what's not and what people believe is ordinary activity and not.

And so you have to calibrate for the fact that the answers that you would give in a place like where I live, which is Santa Clara County in Northern California where, you know, mask wearing is relatively universal and the compliance is pretty high.
You know, that's going to be a very different scenario than if you lived in a place where people, you know, weren't necessarily adopting that point of view.

So I think it's the same advice that I've given to government policymakers, which is, look, if you're going to put in place a restriction, be transparent about what you're trying to do and be clear about why you're doing it.
And I think that advice applies in the individual and family context too.
Let's go to some of these questions and I'm keeping track of these lessons that you're calling out and at the end, we may come back and just confirm them.
We're going to start with a couple of families situations.
I'm going to read one from Beth Lime.
My children are 14, 17 and 20, and we're finding it difficult to manage their social needs with what we believe is appropriately cautious behavior.
Our large and not from the same families, making it difficult to form quarantine bubbles.
By the way, I love that she used to wear bubbles and many of their friends or their friends families are not as serious about distancing or reducing the number of people they interact with as we are.
So how to best keep them and us safe while making sure they're able to stay social and mentally healthy while they feel like their friends are having normal summer with little to no restrictions.
When I've expressed what we believe to be responsible behavior to these families, I met with, we think the kids are fine being close together outside or going in and out of each other's houses.
We are done with this social distancing thing.
So the situation, as you just heard, is probably very common.
People who sounds like they were social distancing at first, but then summer came and they're tired of it and for a variety of reasons, they're not having it any longer.
And you've got young adults, teenagers, young adults who can dig for themselves and aren't feeling particularly a risk.
So what are your thoughts, Londie, and about in a situation like that?
Yeah, well, my kids are nine and six, although my nine-year-old socially likes to think he's going on 15.
So maybe I empathize with the desire to see lots of friends.
I think there's a few points to underscore.
First of all, I completely understand that there are a number of families that are frustrated or that feel like they want to try and resume their normal lives.

And so I guess the first thing I would say is it's important to recognize that while there are different styles of approaching this in terms of what an appropriate amount of social distancing is or what kind of groups and social groups people feel comfortable with, I don't think that, well, I'm put in this way, there is a right way to socially distancing

I don't want to mince words about that, but I do think that it's important not to not to impose judgment on others who are feeling that mental frustration or the mental tiredness that has come with this period of time we've been in.
So recognizing that and understanding that is fully important.
What I tell my own kids about this, and particularly my older one, is that it is good to be able to see people.

And obviously that's an important part of social and mental development for kids is to have the social environments, but trying to explain that these are boundaries that we are setting because we believe that a, we want to do what we can to play our part in the community and to do what needs to be done, but

be also to protect our own family. I find having that explanation and sitting down with the kids and saying, look, we're not saying you can't have no interactions, but we're also saying that you can't have the same interactions you had as before the virus because we know enough now about the virus to know
that these restrictions and some of the things that we're doing are absolutely the right thing to do.
And having that conversation with your own kids first and making sure they understand why you're doing what you're doing, I think is important.
And then having those conversations with other families, maybe trying to gauge what their comfort level is, how they've been engaging in various things, social distancing and otherwise.
And then, you know, making decisions based on what works best for your family. I just don't think anybody can fault one for making decisions based on what's best for their own family.
And we see this in all sorts of different contexts.
So I would approach it first with my own family and kids and then talk a little bit about, you know, trying to gauge with other families, kind of what they've been doing.
And, you know, at the end of the day, you've got to draw lines. You know, we hope it's not for forever, but those lines do have to be drawn now.

Yeah, and I agree. And just a little to add is there are situations where you could say to another family, you know, our kid Joe really wants to see your son Rob, would you guys be willing to like shut it down for five days, seven days, so that they can have, you know, to be in a bubble together?
We know you can't do that long term, but can we figure out something so we can get these kids together? They're such good friends.
How can we do this where we're both comfortable? And again, I think it goes back to the long years advice earlier of just having clear explanations of why you feel this way.
And it's not a judgment on the other family, but what works for your family? I want to know what Zach would say to one of his friends or what his advice is.

Well, we'll see if we can rope back into the conversation. I bet we've, of course, Zach is 18 very responsible and we've had these conversations with him. And I think, you know, Lonnie, your advice, you know, at some level, we're not going to be able to watch our 18 year old or 20 year old or 15 year old, even our 12 year olds, 24 by 7.
And so having them understand and helping them make good decisions and helping them understand the implications is important.
And I'm sure there's times when kids don't listen because that's what kids do.
You know, if you have someone in your house who's immunocompromised and you've got a sticky situation where you think your kid is doing things that are where you're not going to be safe.
And look, we know situations like that. And it's been one where the kids have even been aware that their parents are immunocompromised and still continue to go out because they don't fall.
To go out because they don't feel like it's going to make an impact and then harder lines and harder conversations have had to be drawn.
More from my bubble after the break. Stay with us.

I'm going to read another situation, a family situation. This one sounds pretty challenging.
It's just really around what's like when you're for divorced parents.
From Liz Marks, she says, we do not agree on the severity of the virus or on how strict to be with our kids about contact with others.
Divorce for five years, two kids, worst time to be co-parenting.
Our pediatrician said he's been receiving more calls than ever before about this conflict with parents who are both married and divorced.
Tough to balance the risks that the children's need for interactions.
My ex also blames me for making kids fearful and afraid.
When in reality, I'm making sure they are safe and healthy.
Love to get your thoughts.
So I know neither of you are a marriage or family therapist, counselors, but Natalie, I think you've done a lot of work and a lot of thinking in how people try to cross really difficult barriers.
What advice would you give to Liz?
This is a tough one.

As a kid who had parents who were divorced but very functional in their co-parenting, it's hard to say this given the person's email, but getting on the same page is so important for the health of the kid and trying to figure out a compromise.
And so you're both on the same page.
Having said that, that sounds like that may not be possible in this situation.

So part of my job at United States of Care is to go out and understand people's health care experiences and find where there are commonalities across people and where there are really important differences across different demographics.
And recently with COVID, we've continued to talk to people about their health care experiences and what they need from the health care system and how they're doing during COVID.

And across demographics, we heard that the most pressing concern, when we said what are you concerned about, the most pressing concern people had was the health and safety of their loved ones at 66% followed closely by their own personal health.
And so, you know, if there is a way to lead in these conversations with this joint value of this is about safety for our kids, this is about safety for us.
How can we find middle ground?

Or if there's another thing that these two co-parents have a shared value of, is there a way to ground that in the conversation rather than it feeling like, you know, you're making my kids sick or you're being irresponsible in a world of compromise.
And that's where I would lead. I certainly don't know if I would work in this situation.

Yeah, boy. I mean, this is a tough one, you know, and not even just for parents who are divorced. I mean, I know lots of married couples where the two parents have different views or different standards or different thoughts about how to handle this.
And I do think, you know, getting on the same page is important.
I guess I would say this. I mean, I feel like it's important for both parents to realize, you know, probably not going to get 100% of what you want, probably not going to get 80% of what you want.
You know, I'd settle for 50.1 scenario and doing your best to meet in the middle because understanding that there are all sorts of emotions that are caught up with this pandemic and with this crisis.
There are feelings of anxiety. There are feelings of one questions, one's own decisions sometimes. You know, was this really the right call? Am I being too conservative? Am I being too permissive?

And so I think you have to accept that all those things are swirling in people's heads. And that's going to make it tough to come to a place where you feel 100% comfortable and your spouse or co-parent or, you know, person you're working with feels 100% comfortable as well.
So I think being able to meet in the middle, but recognizing, look, I'm not going to get my ideal world because, you know, we aren't in this alone.
These endeavors in many situations require the intersection, interaction of lots of different people. And so just recognizing that, you know, probably not going to get 100% of what I want.
But what I can do is I can try to get as much agreement as I can and try to meet in the middle. I think that's important.

So this idea of compromise is an interesting one here, right? Because in most situations with, again, parents who are still married, parents who are divorced, this idea of compromise is what makes the world go round.
But what I sense in the letter like this is people who are saying, maybe this is a situation where I can't compromise because, you know, there's an absolute here about health.
And the meeting in the middle of the 50.1% means that my child is interacting and doing things that are unsafe half the time that makes me unsafe.
But I think maybe one way to look at it, given your idea, Lonnie, is can you sit down and create a list of activities that you both agree are reasonably safe.

And likewise, you do the same thing with your kids. And the good news now, I think, is that three or four months into the pandemic, there are a lot of things that I think we didn't really know if they were safe or not that are pretty safe.

Like playing outdoors, like gathering with small groups of people, you know, even some outdoor sports where before it was like, well, we can't touch the same baseball bat because of, you know, it's a surface.
You know, we're a lot less worried about surfaces now, we're a lot more worried about aerosols.

Now, I think these sort of orthogonal approaches where you find your your budding heads and there's no room for movement, taking a different angle or a different direction or having the conversation begin at a completely different place that builds some commonality and some positivity.
And you agree?
I loved Natalie's suggestion earlier that you sit down every two weeks because things are changing so fast.
And part of the problem is people are like, wait a minute, I thought I wasn't supposed to do that.
Oh, now maybe I can.
Oh, I thought that was say, oh, now it's not or now that I'm working, this is different because I'm coming into contact with different people.

This idea of sitting down every couple weeks and saying, okay, let's put it all on the table again and see if we're comfortable with more things or if there's things we're comfortable with before that we're not.

There's one more version of this type of question, which is actually the reverse, which is people whose older parents are much more doubting or skeptical of the need to socially distance and wear a mask.
And, you know, I've got an article in front of me from Health Affairs, which I know you've both seen, which says that over the course of the last couple months, masks have probably prevented
230,000 to 450,000 infections.
Now, someone could also pull out a study, I'm sure, which says that masks don't work if they want.
And such is the nature of the Internet age when you can find anything you want to confirm your point of view and all the things you both emphasized.
You know, you've mentioned reason in facts, but you've mentioned much more about understanding people and emotions.
So, you know, shoving these reports in people's face may work for some people, depending how you do it, but maybe not for others.

And here I get the sense that there may be two different TV news sources going on where parents are getting their news from a conservative channel and the kids are getting their news from a progressive channel or a liberal channel.
I'm reading through that.
But the issue here is that the older parents, the mother has pulmonary hypertension, diabetes, and is on oxygen.
The father continues to go to the office, grocery appointments, etc.
And she still goes out into the world and gets haircuts and nails, etc.
They live in Arizona, where the virus has not been taken seriously.
These are their words, but I would say in general, that's been the case up until at least recently.

She is also trying to keep her distance from her parents, and she is trying to figure out how to be firm and give them the kind of response to let them know that by remaining in her own bubble, she is helping keep them safe.
She wants to know if she should ask them to agree to live under those same restrictions in order to feel comfortable in letting them into her bubble.
So, opposite situation from the kids, but same kind of reality.
Lonnie, any thoughts quickly on this one?
Yeah, I mean, a few things. First of all, on the mask wearing, this has been a source of frustration to me because I think, you know, there are a series of things we can do in our lives.

Some of them are harder than others. I understand that it's very, very difficult to, for example, the scenarios that have been raised around kids and social settings and want to go out and play baseball.
And I get all that. I fully understand the frustration there.
Mask wearing is a relatively simple intervention in the grand scheme of things, and it should not be as controversial or fraught as it is and has become.

Now, part of that, I would say, goes back to the conflicting guidance we got at the start of this, and I understand why that was the case, but I think when I've talked to some people who have been skeptical about mask wearing, they said, well, look, a couple months ago, I was told I didn't need to wear a mask.

Now I'm being told I need to wear a mask. What's the deal? So I get that. But part of this is about communicating to those, and this includes parents, this includes older people who may themselves be at risk, that mask wearing is important because it is a relatively easy way to deal with some of the challenges created by this virus.

That's the first thing. The second thing is, I would say, in your own behavior, in your own way that you deal with parents or deal with those who might have conditions, that makes your wearing of a mask even more important.
And to model that behavior and to say, look, this is something that we're going to do because we want to protect you and really making clear. That's the reason.
It's not about protecting me as much as it is about protecting you. I think that's an important message that oftentimes doesn't get conveyed nearly enough.

In terms of making restrictions, and here again, I think, Andy, your thoughts about sitting down and saying, look, here's a list of things that we think is okay, then the parents put in here to list the things that they think is okay, and trying to figure out some way to triangulate to a set of activities that is okay so people are comfortable.

To me, the idea of, let's say, going out to eat on an outdoor patio or going to a store but ensuring that you're wearing a mask, those are things that, to me, feel a lot less risky than some of the other things that are being mentioned.
But again, you don't really know until you sit down and look at the things that, yes, I think these are okay. No, I don't think these are okay.
Having that same conversation, I think the same advice applies even though the situation is turned on its head a little bit.

So if you had to convince someone to wear a mask who hasn't wanted to, or if you haven't, how might you, knowing that, as you say, you know people who are skeptical, how might you go about doing that? What's the best approach or approach?

Yeah, well, look, I have found for a lot of people who don't want to wear a mask, the idea of saying here are five more studies that say you should wear a mask, that's not really that compelling to that group of folks because it is a lot less about what the science is telling them or a lot less about what conventional
sources are telling them and it's more just about their feeling or their sense that they're being told what to do.

And so, you know, rather than trying to give them the data or rather than trying to give them a paper, what I try to do is I try to talk a little bit about why I make the decision and when I wear a mask and when I don't wear a mask and why it's important and helping them understand that they have some agency in this.
I know that sounds a little bit ironic, but I think helping them understand they have some agency in this decision and making the right decision is entirely in their hands.
I think what a lot of people object to that I've spoken to who are skeptical about this is the idea that they're being told what to do.
And so, I don't try to tell anybody what to do. I try to say, look, here's why I make the decision I make.
I would hope you'd arrive at the same decision that I would.
If you want to see evidence or you want me to tell you more about the data I've seen, I am more than happy to tell you about that.
You know, I think the approach that ends up being least effective, unfortunately, is the one where I said, well, gosh, there's another study out.
And look, you know, I'm hearing this today on the news. It's really more about, look, here are the factors that I've borne in mind.
Is it an inconvenience to throw the thing on before I go out every time? Yeah, sure it is.
But given the potential risks it avoids, for me at least, I believe that's a step I want to take and here's why.
Helping people to arrive at that conclusion on their own rather than, you know, shaming them or gilting them or saying, look, here's what the authorities are telling you to do.
I think that unfortunately only provokes the opposite response.
Right. So don't make somebody feel stupid or boxed them in. Natalie, anything you did?
I think there's two things I would say, shame does not work, I think, ever, but especially here, making them feel stupid or that they are going against what experts are saying.
I think what work. And I think the other thing that's going to be really hard is not taking it personally when someone decides not to.
I think the entire approach, you know, is exactly right and why it's important to me.
And it's not that big of a deal. And here's how we can get together. Like the positive of this is that we get to hang out now.
So just please put it on. But if they decide not to, it's really hard, but it kind of has to be a, okay, that was your decision.
This is my decision, see in a year or see if you change your mind or if we have a vaccine or, you know, there's another way to get together.
But if there's a way to kind of divorce their action from how they feel about you is going to be really important for all of our mental health.
So we don't have this resentment and anger and real corrosion of relationships occur.
Yeah, I'm going to add one thing to what you guys said, which is a great list to tell people you love them.
